awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Novel Statistical Tools for Metagenomics and Metabolomics Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Accumulating evidence suggests that disrupting intestinal microbial ecosystems can cause many serious diseases including chronic diseases such as coronary heart disease (CHD), neurobehavioral diseases such as autism, inflammatory diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and etc. For example, the developing infant intestinal microbiome has been implicated in central myelination and the maturation and function of microglia (CNS immune cells), a core deficiency in Autism Spectrum Disorders. Thus, the study of the gut microbial distributions and their metabolites are very important to find new therapeutic targets for many diseases. However, compared to the huge amounts of medical research on human cells, our understanding of the microbial ecosystem is very limited: the biodiversity of them is barely studied, not to mention their interactions with the human host. This project will develop a suite of statistical theory and methods as well as computational tools to facilitate the understanding of the intestinal microbial ecosystem. The proposed methods are fast, efficient, and highly accurate. They can be widely applied to any metagenomic and metabolomic investigations. Graduate students will be trained by participating in research activities.
  
The main goal of this project is to extend our knowledge of intestinal microbial ecosystem by developing novel quantitative methods for microbial species and their metabolites detection, identification, and quantification in various diseases.  The sensitivity and specificity of our methods permit accurate detection of microbial species at very low coverage levels. This is a translational technology that should find substantial use in biomedical researches and drug developments. More specifically, the PIs shall develop methods for identifying microbial species especially unknown species, reducing error in metabolomic analysis, estimating microbial and metabolite distributions, quantifying microbial or metabolites distributional differences that are associated with diseases, integrating metagenomic and metabolomic analysis together to study the microbial ecosystem, building analytical models to link metabolite profiling with species profiling to understand how metabolites interact with genetic contents and eventually affect cell metabolism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The joint project aims at developing statistical inference framework and computational tools for deriving metabolites distribution from integrated MS and NMR data. Through identifying differentially distributed metabolites or microbial species, we attempt to link metabolites with microbial species, which then leads to a better prediction and understanding (how microbiome is related) of the coronary heart disease. Our side focuses more on methodological developments. To facilitate an efficient comparison of different distributions, we have developed a few complementary nonparametric tests to compare distributions of different samples, which are then generalized to testing nonlinear relationships. We have provided rigorous theoretical support for the optimality of the tests we proposed -- they are essentially the best one can do for a large class of distributions. 

We developed two novel methods for variable selection with accurate false discovery rate (FDR) controls for high-dimensional linear models: the Gaussian mirror and data splitting (DS) methods. We have shown that these methods a simpler to implement and have comparable to better powers than the popular knockoff approaches. This DS method is particularly attractive since it is simple to implement, easily parallizable, robust, and broadly applicable. Its application to generalized linear models leads to high-powered variable selection methods that have reliable FDR controls under both high, low, and moderate dimensional settings, significantly improves the power and inference accuracy of existing methods that rely on asymptotic normality. The grant also supported us to conduct some general theoretical studies for understanding the impact of ranking algorithm, design matrix, and mirror statistics for the power of some popular FDR control methods.

We have also developed a unified Bayesian sparsity prior framework for though the use of an activation function (called the "neuronized prior") The framework can include many existing popular priors such as horeseshoe and spike-and-slab priors, and enables more efficient MCMC computations. This is a very general framework and has been successfully applied to predict genetic risks in genome-wide association studies with significant improvements over existing methods. It can also be applied to link metabolites with microbial species. Another area of theoretical study is to develop methods to aggregate and analyze rank data. This may be applicable to provide a more robust way of clustering samples with different microbial species distributions and then link to metabolites. 

On the bioinformatics side, we have developed a general framework for Bayesian biclustering and showing how it can be applied to solve important challenges such as discovering genes in a functional module, clustering cells based on single-cell sequencing data, and revealing key genetic variants that may underlie certain common traits. The method can also be applied to microbiome data to discover distinctive subsets of microbial species that may be present in a significant subset of the samples. We have also worked on human genetics data, combining difference sources of information that leverages personal genome information to prioritize non-coding variants, and applied our developed Bayesian neuronized prior-based regression method to improve polygenetic risk predictions.
